rsbNotes.title: Matt 8–9
rsbNotes.text: 8:1–9:38 The order of the miracles and events in these chapters differs from that found in Mark and Luke. Probably Matthew arranged them according to topic rather than chronology.

rsbNotes.title: Matt 9:2
rsbNotes.text: 9:2 your sins are forgiven. Forgiveness is the prerogative of the one who has been offended, and for Jesus to forgive sins was to claim divine authority (Is. 43:25).

rsbNotes.title: Matt 9:5
rsbNotes.text: 9:5 which is easier. Ultimately, forgiving sins is more difficult than performing a miracle, as the scribes would know since they recognized that only God can forgive sins. But the forgiveness of sins cannot be seen by observers. Jesus performs the lesser deed to prove the greater.

rsbNotes.title: Matt 9:11
rsbNotes.text: 9:11 Just as Jesus was not defiled by contact with lepers, so He was not defiled by contact with sinners. He is the Physician who heals spiritual as well as physical sickness. Those who thought they were well were puzzled by Jesus’ activities and found Him offensive.

rsbNotes.title: Matt 9:14
rsbNotes.text: 9:14 disciples of John. Although Luke notes that Pharisees asked about fasting, Mark includes both John’s disciples and Pharisees among those who raised the question.

rsbNotes.title: Matt 9:15
rsbNotes.text: 9:15 then they will fast. Jesus explained that because He was present as the Messiah, His disciples did not need to fast. Jesus recognizes a future time when the bridegroom will not be with them. This points out that, from the earliest stages of His ministry, Jesus anticipated a time between His initial coming in redemption and His final coming in the Judgment.

rsbNotes.title: Matt 9:17
rsbNotes.text: 9:17 new wine put into old wineskins. New wine continues to ferment and builds up pressure that would burst a used wineskin. The old patterns of fasting are inappropriate for the fullness of the kingdom that has now arrived.
